topic: Civil War and Revolution in China
readings: What Women Should Know About Communism (He Zhen)

readingAnalyses.title: What Women Should Know About Communism
readingAnalyses.author: He Zhen (何震)
readingAnalyses.summary:
He Zhen was one of early 20th-century China's most radical voices—an anarchist-feminist who argued that women's liberation required destroying not just capitalism but the entire family system. Writing from Tokyo exile around 1907, she attacked reformers who wanted to 'improve' women's conditions without fundamentally transforming society. Half-measures, she argued, would only create new forms of exploitation.

Her analysis linked gender, class, and national oppression: Chinese women were enslaved by fathers, husbands, and employers; China itself was enslaved by foreign powers; both oppressions stemmed from the same system of hierarchy and exploitation. Liberation required revolution on all fronts simultaneously.

He Zhen's radicalism went beyond what even the Communist Party would later embrace. She criticized state socialism as another form of domination; true liberation required abolishing all authority. Her vision wasn't realized, but her questions—how do gender, class, and nation intersect?—continued to shape Chinese revolutionary thought.

keyQuotes.quote: Under the present system, women are doubly oppressed—by capitalism and by the family.
Those who would 'improve' women's conditions without revolution merely create new forms of slavery.
Liberation of women and liberation of workers are the same struggle.

One-child policy and women's bodies as sites of state control
Contemporary Chinese feminism's struggles against both traditional and socialist patriarchy
Global debates about whether liberation requires revolution or reform

overallSynthesis:
He Zhen's writings reveal the radical vision that animated Chinese revolutionary movements—and the compromises those movements would later make. Her anarchist feminism connected all forms of oppression: gender, class, nation. True liberation required destroying the family, the state, and capitalism simultaneously. Anything less was reformism.

The Chinese Communist Party would adopt some of her rhetoric while abandoning her anarchism. Land reform, women's rights, and anti-imperialism became revolutionary slogans. But the CCP built a powerful state rather than abolishing state power; reformed the family rather than destroying it; and created new hierarchies while claiming to abolish hierarchy. He Zhen's questions about whether state socialism could deliver genuine liberation remain relevant.

This reading connects to the course's broader themes. The Taiping Rebellion (Plate 13) showed radical alternatives to Confucian order; He Zhen offered another. Both were suppressed or marginalized, but both revealed that China's revolutionary tradition included visions far more radical than what actually triumphed. Understanding what was imagined—and what was foreclosed—helps us see that history wasn't inevitable.
executiveSummary:
The Chinese Communist revolution was not just about class struggle—it was also about gender revolution. He Zhen (c. 1884-c. 1920) was a radical anarchist-feminist who argued that women's liberation required destroying both capitalism and the family system. Her writings reveal how Chinese revolutionaries connected economic, political, and gender oppression into a comprehensive critique of traditional society.

The broader context is China's descent into civil war between Nationalists (Guomindang) and Communists (1927-1949), interrupted by Japanese invasion (1937-1945). Both parties claimed to represent Sun Yat-sen's revolutionary legacy; both promised to cure China's weakness. The Communists ultimately won not just through military victory but by mobilizing peasants—and women—with promises of land reform and social transformation.

keyPassages.quote: Women are the slaves of slaves. The liberation of women requires the destruction of the family, private property, and the state.
The Chinese revolution must be a revolution of women as well as of men, or it will be no revolution at all.

keyQuestions.question: How did Chinese revolutionaries connect gender oppression to other forms of oppression?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: He Zhen saw women's oppression as rooted in family/property/state. Feet binding, arranged marriage, lack of education all connected. Communist women's policies (marriage reform, education) followed this logic.

keyQuestions.question: Why did the Communists win the civil war?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Multiple factors: peasant mobilization through land reform, Nationalist corruption and inflation, Japanese war weakened GMD more than CCP, Mao's guerrilla strategy. Not inevitable—GMD had advantages too.

keyQuestions.question: Did the Communist revolution actually liberate women?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Marriage reform, education, workforce participation all increased. But party remained male-dominated; 'women hold up half the sky' rhetoric didn't match reality. Progress was real but limited.

teachingNotes: He Zhen is less famous than male revolutionaries but represents important strand of thought.
Students may expect 'revolution = Communism.' Show the diversity of revolutionary visions (anarchist, feminist, nationalist).
The civil war is complex—avoid simple 'good guys vs. bad guys' framing.
Gender dimension often overlooked in political history. He Zhen reading corrects this.
Web links to Chen Duxiu, Chiang, and Mao provide additional context.
